SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: NSA collecting phone records of millions of Verizon customers daily

It's funny to hear how, when Bush was in office, this kind of thing was "an outrage" coming from the left. But now that it's their Prez doing it, suddenly it's no big deal. I didn't like the Patriot Act before and I still don't like it from one President to another. It's too broad-scoped open for abuse by politicians and other government officials. So what does that make me?

It's funny to hear how, when Bush was in office, this kind of thing was "an outrage" coming from the left. But now that it's their Prez doing it, suddenly it's no big deal. I didn't like the Patriot Act before and I still don't like it from one President to another. It's too broad-scoped open for abuse by politicians and other government officials. So what does that make me?

Also, initially the NSA was only following overseas leads picked up by listening in on calls, emails, texts, etc if they were going from the U.S. to other countries. That's what got us started on figuring out where Bin Laden was. Then, once they established who the people were who were connected to Bin Laden, if they came here, they were followed by the NSA and FBI. Otherwise, the NSA might notify the CIA as to the whereabouts and "whatabouts" of these people. But there weren't initially just blindly listening to practically everyone in the U.S. That may be something that, while the Patriot Act was started under Bush, wasn't an intended operation. It may be something started by the current administration. If it is, it really makes one wonder if it's being used to find and stop domestic terrorism, or is it being used in a more Nixon-like way? The NSA's computers scan for key words to tag a usable lead. Makes one wonder what those key words are now. Are they words like "bomb" and "jihad," or are they, like the recent IRS problems, words like "patriot" and "Constitution?" Anyway, here's a cool movie by Nova that shows how the NSA used to operate. It's apparent that they do things differently now.
Both gave up everything dear to them simply based on principal. Classic heroes.
But let's put the focus back where it belongs: the poor conduct of the US government.

<a href="/watch?v=_Z99qFwsDmU" class="yt-uix-sessionlink yt-uix-tile-link yt-ui-ellipsis yt-ui-ellipsis-2 spf-link " data-sessionlink="itct=CBcQ3DAYASITCJqWvKy7s8cCFYmOqgodGMgEqSj0JFITbWVldCBlZHdhcmQgc25vd2Rlbg" title="Meet Edward Snowden: NSA PRISM Whistleblower" rel="spf-prefetch" aria-describedby="description-id-92334" dir="ltr">Meet Edward Snowden: NSA PRISM Whistleblower</a>

He "says" he was selective in what information he exposed. That's a key difference in what Bradley Manning did. Bradley Manning just took whatever he could get his hands on. There should be punishment for both as they both leaked classified information and they knew that was a no-no going into their jobs. I suppose whether or not I, or anyone else, feel better about this will come down to whether the guy simply exposed what was going on or did he provide names and operations that may endanger lives. Bradley Manning had his information put up on a public webpage for all to see. I don't think this guy did that. Although I really need to read into it more. Time will tell I suppose.
Are we glad this information got out to us?
Do we feel the same way about the guy who leaked this information as we do about the Wikileaks guy?
Both gave up everything dear to them simply based on principal. Classic heroes.
But let's put the focus back where it belongs: the poor conduct of the US government.
The following is incomplete. Please feel free to help me tweak it. I hope to get it published as a national opinion piece maybe in a major newspaper.
These were mr. president's first remarks on this NSA scandal.
"If you can not trust your President, if you can not trust Congress, if you can not trust your judges, we have a problem".
Really mr. president ? That is an understatement. We have a really big problem.

Trust you mr. president ? Ha ! When you were asked point blank if anybody in the White House knew about the IRS scandal, you instead answer that the first time "you" heard of the scandal was in the news when we the public did. Don't insult us with your lies mr. president. Not to bore you with details mr. president but I will point out a few. We know you will want to insulate yourself from them yet the lies of your administration are yours. Jay Carney saying the White House only changed one small detail in the Benghazi Blunder talking points, which turned out to be a total distortion of the facts. The assertion that it was low level dweebs in the IRS who targeted your enemies. The assertion that there was an uptick in 501(c)(4)'s when the actual number went down. The judge shopping of which your third judge allowed our freedoms of the press to be violated. Your Attorney General denying and saying he had never heard of a potential prosecution of a journalist despite seeking a search warrant against him. I could go on. I will leave out your agenda of which though you barely won (with the help of the IRS), you declare that you have a mandate. I can't dismiss ObamaCare (which the IRS was also complicit in passing). Every thing you said was wrong, even the unions are upset. If you are not a liar mr. president, you are incompetent. You ask me to trust you, <img src="http://www.fiero.nl/forum/eek.gif"> ? Do you have any idea how many times your administration has been asked questions by Congress or the press and your administration's answer has been "I don't know" ? Or how about when the Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, was asked in March of this year if they were doing the exact same citizen spying thing, he said "no". Some other yahoo was asked if members of Congress had their records surveiled and hem hawed an answer, which was not "no".

Trust our Congress mr. president ? Really ? Have you seen their approval rating ? They couldn't even vote themselves out of insider trading laws. As recently as today we hear the SEC (Security Exchange Committee) is investigating government workers in soaring stock sales to companies which will be involved in ObamaCare. The failure of the Senate to pass a budget in four years, the partisanship divide, the tyranny of Senator Harry Reid not letting votes come up in "your" democratic party controlled Senate. The list of distrust is longer for Congress than yours mr. president.

Judges. We should trust them ? Why didn't your Attorney General trust the first two judges who turned him down for seeking a search warrant for that Fox News reporter's private 4th amendment rights? Judges are politically appointed hacks, in many cases picked to rule from the bench. The FISA (Foreign Intelligence and Surveillance Act) court which handles your requests for citizen surveilence is a secret court which it seems has rubber stamped your every single request. Your Dept of Justice is fighting to stop the release of the secret court opinion on the unlawful surveillance of Americans. You want us to trust the same judges you berated in your 2010 State of the Union address ?

We would like to trust in our government mr. president. The problem with that mr. president, is that now, we do not trust in the system. As that IRS Tea Party victim said, our government has lost it's way. It is bad enough about our scandalous national debt mr. president but do you really think that we have trust that gooberment's spending problem can be curtailed ? The fact that we are a union of States yet the federal system sues States for enacting mirror laws of the feds to enforce them when the feds won't and you sue them ? The use of our money to extort us into enacting your wishes, by withholding federal dollars until we do. The wasteful spending whether it be on $500.00 hammers to the extravagance in spending for conventions, many with dubious activities. The printing of 85 billion a month to inject money into the economy. That bill will become due. The cryin' and whinin' about how government can't survive with a 2% reduction in spending increases and in your punishing the citizens in an extortion attempt for us to put pressure on our Congressional leaders. This country was founded to escape exactly what we find that we have now.

You say mr. president that you welcome a public conversation on this issue. Why didn't you start one before you were found out ? How can we discuss this if we can not even know the details or even the scope of nature of this. You patronize us by saying that you added safeguards. Assure us mr. president. What are they, or are they classified too ? You say that we can not have 100% security and 100% privacy, and 0% inconvenience. You are the decider of what we will accept ? Or, are you the dictator of what we can expect ? We hate the used car salesman tactic that gooberment uses. "It's for the children", et al. If it's for our own good mr. president and we accept it, how soon will you be targeting the enemies in the war on drugs ? What about our gun rights ? We won't need a national gun registry if you can just monitor the words gun or ammunition and target gun web sights. What is the difference between the security of America and the security of Amerika ? Our gooberment has already proved it will target those with a different opinion of the regime in charge. You are quoted as saying you will punish you enemies and reward your friends.
Trust our government mr. president ? Puleeze. Yes mr.s president, we have a problem.
Just to be sure you hear me mr. president, let me add some keywords.
ricin, Al Quida, Tea Party, Constitution, Israel, communism, fascist, democracy, secede, bomb, terrorist, martial law, overthrow, revolt, gun rights, drugs,
Cliff you know if you mail it, you will never be heard from again, right? while I agree with it I think you better find some big news media to post that anonymously.
If my carrier did it, they will be dropped.
Are we glad this information got out to us?
Do we feel the same way about the guy who leaked this information as we do about the Wikileaks guy?

Edward Snowden, who currently works for defense contractor Booz Allen Hamilton, told the Guardian that he knows there will punishment for exposing the classified information, but said, I'm willing to sacrifice all of that because I can't in good conscience allow the US government to destroy privacy, internet freedom and basic liberties for people around the world with this massive surveillance machine they're secretly building."
Now I have to put up or shut up, <img src="http://www.fiero.nl/forum/frown.gif">.

The guy is a hero. With a lame stream media (the people's check and balance) and the targeting of journalists, whistle blowers are all that we have to depend on. This guy risked his life, sacrificed it, just as much as any armed services person ever did. More gooberment workers, if they are a public servant, need to do the same.
Steve, see the end of my last post. I will not be scared.

Politicians have started reading their scripts:

"If Edward Snowden did in fact leak the NSA data as he claims, the United States government must prosecute him to the fullest extent of the law and begin extradition proceedings at the earliest date," King, a New York Republican, said in a written statement. "The United States must make it clear that no country should be granting this individual asylum. This is a matter of extraordinary consequence to American intelligence."
The Republican head of the House intelligence committee, Mike Rogers, said Snowden had "released just enough information to literally be dangerous".
Rand Paul, in support of Snowden, says he's going to challenge this issue at the supreme court level.
It wouldn't surprise me if this were true, but Snowden may be a Ron Paul supporter.
Julian Assange says "Edward Snowden is a "hero" who has exposed "one of the most serious events of the decade the creeping formulation of a mass surveillance state.""
